title: Wednesday, 30th May, 2018

Martin Sorrell is to return to the public markets after striking a reverse takeover of Derriston Capital, a cash shell, with the aim of building a marketing and communications services group in the mould of WPP.

Sir Martin has created a new vehicle called S4 Capital which is to be acquired by Derriston, according to a stock exchange announcement on Wednesday morning. He will become the London-listed company’s executive chairman and has injected £40m of his own funds into the venture, with other backers providing £11m. S4 Capital has also received non-binding commitments from institutional investors for more than £150m worth of extra funds.

BE11:09am

And skipping a bit ...........

11:09 am
BE11:09am

[Sir Martin] left WPP in April following a board investigation into an unspecified allegation of personal misconduct, which Sir Martin denies. WPP has declined to comment on the nature of the allegation, something which has angered some shareholders.

BE11:10am

Okay. April 14th, if I remember correctly.

BE11:11am

It's now May 30th. Nearly seven weeks.

BE11:22am

Having been upbeat about the outlook for the eurozone for the past 18 months, these past few weeks have not been easy. Underwhelming growth data, underwhelming inflation data, higher oil prices, simmering trade tensions, heightened angst about some emerging economies and – to cap it all off – growing investor alarm about political and economic stability in Italy (as well as Spain).
Many of these factors – and those European political issues in particular ‒ were not part of our original script. And as such we have had to rethink our economic and ECB policy outlook. More specifically, we have made the following changes to our outlook:
– We have lowered our GDP growth forecast for 2018 to 2.1% from 2.4%. Our forecast for 2019 has been lowered to 1.8% from 2.0%.
– We now expect the ECB to announce a three-month wind-down of its asset purchase programme from October through to December 2018 at the July meeting. We had previously expected a shorter two-month wind-down. More significantly, we now expect the lift-off in policy rates to commence in September 2019. We had previously assumed that this would occur next March. We think it more probable too that recent financial instability and slower growth could encourage the ECB to become more explicit in its forward guidance, possibly by suggesting what it means by its current statement that interest rate hikes will not emerge until “well past the horizon of the net asset purchases”.

Excel Developer @kim: LIBOR or EURIBOR?
11:22 am
BE11:22am

These changes to our view are importantly conditional on some reversal of the trend toward financial instability that has gripped Italy in recent days and which threatens to grip other European economies in the coming weeks. And at present there are no clear catalysts that might generate that reversal. That obviously means that the risks to our economic outlook are tilted to the downside. By extension, it means the ECB may well postpone even further its plans for policy normalisation and possibly even contemplate putting them into reverse.
As for the direct policy issues for the ECB that concern Italy, we do not believe – at this stage ‒ that any overt statements of support or policy interventions are likely. We think it more likely that we will get some clarification that the monetary policy toolkit – including the asset purchase programme (APP) – is deployed for very different purposes than, say, the outright monetary transactions programme (OMT). The latter is designed instead to tackle redenomination risk. However, it still requires strict conditionality (a so-called Memorandum of Understanding (MOU)) and, of more significance, follows – and does not precede – some support from a financial sovereign programme (e.g. the EFSF/ESM). That means we could still be a long way from a point where the OMT programme could be activated.

kim EURIBOR (sorry, didn't look at the basis).
Excel Developer coz Euribor 3m is at -0.322% (not the minus)
Excel Developer (*note* the minus)
BE11:23am

Don't lose sleep over Italy, is the upshot. Elsewhere's fine.

BE11:24am

– A still-healthy backdrop and outlook for global growth. As our US team has been arguing, the US economy is poised for a healthy rebound in Q2, and more generally should generate sturdy economic activity from super-loose fiscal policy, still-loose financial conditions and healthy underlying income and profit momentum in the immediate months ahead. China is admittedly more likely to enter a slowdown phase, but its momentum so far this year has been stronger than expected and there are no suggestions yet from the incoming data that it will slow decisively and sap global growth in a material way.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

While Italy poses risks, the domestic growth outlook for the eurozone is still healthy. Incoming data for Q1 and Q2 have certainly been disappointing. But many of the region’s consumer and business confidence gauges are still close to record highs. Financial and monetary conditions are still very loose and, importantly, the latter are generating more growth-friendly banking sector conditions. We note too that the slowdown in Q1 appears to have been induced by weaker export demand, a function in turn of a temporary slowdown in global growth. The latter appears to now be moving into reverse and, in the meantime, the domestic demand foundations of the eurozone’s revival remain quite healthy.

Grouchmonkey Any grey on the phoenix rights issue?
BE11:24am

One of the reasons, moreover, for a still-promising growth outlook is the absence of any glaring imbalances within the eurozone. Most economies are sitting on healthy current account surpluses, much-improved sovereign debt positions and with few, if any, private credit excesses to work off. Should financial instability in Italy, in other words, generate more instability in other eurozone economies, the economic fall-out should be quite small. At the same time as this, there is greater scope for proactive fiscal policy to fend off any growth sapping consequences. We note here – for the record – that our model simulations of bond market instability in Italy with some modest financial spillovers for the periphery do not generate large spillover effects for the eurozone as a whole.

kim Hard to find an excuse to use OMT to help a state whose actions are the cause of the problems.

This explains the lesser sensitivity of other issuers in relation to Italy compared with 2011-2012, as underlined by the most recent market developments.
One can therefore expect contagion to be less that it was during the 2011-2012 sovereign debt crisis

11:28 am
BE11:28am

Where do we see sovereign spreads and German yields
heading in this context?
The integration or not of an Quitaly premium is the main difference
between the best- and worst-case scenarios, with a peak in
sovereign spreads expected in September when the general
election could be held (it is at latest over this horizon that M5S and
The League will have to start cosying up rather more to the
markets).
Assuming as a starting point that investors will at the very least
integrate a sharp deterioration in the fiscal situation, Italy’s debt will
be downgraded by BBB-. Even before considering a drop to junk
over a longer horizon, this would floor the 10-year BTP-Bund spread
at 250bp.
With the integration of an Quitaly premium (worst-case
scenario), a 450bp floor becomes conceivable, which would be
less than the high recorded 5 years ago (552bp at its widest). In this
event, the BTP curve would be flat, possibly inverted, as happened
back in 2011-2012.
The contagion to France and Spain would be relatively limited even
in this scenario, with a widening of the OAT-Bund spread and
SPGB-Bund spread to 100bp and 220bp, respectively. In the
case of OAT, they could potentially be affected by a flight of non-
European investors.

BE11:29am

Concerning German yields, one would probably see the yield for the 2-year Schatz pull back below 1% and the yield for the German 10-year Bund move tentatively into negative territory, the appreciation potential also depending on the news flow out of Europe and the ECB’s next decisions. All in all the BTP-Bund spread should react primarily to M. Salvini and L. Di Maio as regards the single currency and whether they decide to make it the main topic of the upcoming election.

PHTM has warned of a deterioration in trading in its Japan photo-booths business, driving downgrades to forecasts. In FY18, previous trends continued, with strong growth in its laundry business, up 49% YoY, and soft trading in photo-booths across Europe. However, Japan saw significant capacity increases against the launch of the My Number card, and since this is not mandatory, take up remains low, and there has been no volume growth. Profits for FY18 will be "broadly in line" with expectations, but only because of a £3.7m one-off gain in its shareholding in Hong Kong listed Max Sight, implying an underlying downgrade of 8%. Net cash at £26m is £20m below forecast, reflecting higher capex/working capital investment in laundry. For FY19, the impact from Japan will be greater. It plans a "thorough restructuring" of its Japan business, but expects FY19 profits to be broadly in line with FY18, implying a c.15% downgrade. Shares have been weak ahead of statement, and it expects to maintain dividend policy - ie 8.4p for FY18. On a 16.8x cal 2018 PER, backed by 5.6% dividend yield. But we expect shares will go lower.

On the call, management explained that much of this was driven by one-off factors such as weather and significant management changes at Jawoll (Germany). Overall, the tone of the conference call conveyed confidence in the longer-term story, which is driven by a continued store roll-out, enhancements in the product offer, and tight cost control. We view B&M as a strong operator with a meaningful runway for growth. However, at c18x CY19 P/E vs. general retail peers (ex pureplay e-commerce) at c13x, we think this has been priced in. We are Equal Weight.

The Prelims are in line with hopes in the UK, which is a stellar effort given that March LFL was -6%. Germany was a little weaker in FY18 but in general it has been a splendid year for B&M. LFL has bounced back pleasingly since March’s nadir: 3% LFL for April and May is a very good effort given the mostly unhelpful weather and the apparent problems on the High Street. What this all tells us is that the investment case here is bang intact. Shoppers are clearly trading down, but the extended ranges at B&M are winning new customers too. We expect continued strong upgrade momentum to re-emerge here (even if there’s no change to forecasts today: there was never going to be given the weather), and 16x PE for FY19 is extremely good value we think. BUY to 500p.
